I bought it on sale on Steam to support these game makers even further, because they made a bonafide masterpiece when they made Hades.

This isn't going to be a very detailed review. Hades looks fantastic, sounds even better, and plays with the energy of an isometric DOOM game. You play as Zagreus, son of Hades, whose goal is to escape the Underworld, uncovering mysteries, meeting distinct, well-defined characters, and tearing up the scenery along the way. The game unfolds in such an elegant, natural way. The house of Hades seems to expand every time you "die" and return home, there's an ever-expanding codex to learn more info about the game's characters, enemies, and items, and the feeling of progression just seems to continue for a huge length of time, well past what I would expect. That strengthens the feeling that the game just doesn't get old or stop being fun.

I've obviously spent too many hours on this game, grinding for every single achievement, but it's incredibly entertaining. Every single run is difficult in its own way, but none the less super fun.

It's been a while since my first run-through (over a year now), but I think I remember it taking me 30-40 hours to clear it the first time. However, you get much more than 40 hours of game play for the twenty-five dollar price. The magic with Hades is that even after unlocking everything and beating it, it's still incredibly fun to play and tons to do. You can try a variety of different builds to escape hell as well as accomplish side quests while continuing to build relationships with the characters. Along with the beautiful soundtrack and graphics, the ability to be creative with each run makes it engaging, as well as being able to fine-tune the difficulty level and decide for yourself what challenges you'd like to overcome. 

A fun little thing to do once you've completed the game: search up the voice actors for each character. I gained a newfound appreciation for them and their range, as several actors voice characters that sound completely different from each other. I'm not surprised that this game was hailed as one of 2020's best games of the year. While I've exhausted it for now, I'm looking forward to playing in a new save file in a few years to relive the experience :')

An absolutely addictive and fantastic game. Though I've clocked >500 hours on it at this point, I probably clocked 100 of them in just the first month I played in Early Access. I wore permanent fingertip-shaped grooves in my keyboard cover. My arm was pretty displeased with me back then, but it was worth it. And I'm way overdue for writing a review on this game.

[b]Characters:[/b] There isn't a single character I don't like in this game. Even good ol' Theseus is written in a way where you love to "hate" him. Zagreus is a great main character with an excellent balance of humor, compassion, and determination as he blazes his way through the Underworld and meets a host of interesting beings along the way. The gods and goddesses are all written with strikingly unique personalities while still maintaining that common thread that these are powerful beings with a lot of pride, and they will smite you should you slight them. Then there's your allies along the way, including those at home and a unique character in each part of the Underworld to give you moral support and a boost or item. [spoiler]Bouldy is the best boulder of all time.[/spoiler]

[b]Relationships:[/b] Many of Zagreus's most important relationships, whether familial or otherwise, have a rather rocky start to them, and it's a delight to see him develop together with the other characters to come to an understanding, forming an even stronger bond out of all the adversity. It's also very nice that Zagreus can pick whether he has a platonic or romantic relationship with certain characters, and the game allows him to have a male love interest, a female love interest, or both! Zagreus shows what a big heart he has through repairing others' relationships as well, and it's lovely to see second chances work out.

[b]Plot:[/b] While the main gist of the story may seem obvious from the get-go (in other words, escaping the Underworld), there are still surprises to be had along the way and at the end. Without going into spoiler territory, there is certainly more in store than one might think. Plus, what's enjoyable about this game isn't just the main plot but every subplot woven expertly through it. There are plenty of fun quests to execute and character developments to get invested in advancing. It'll keep you hooked.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] There's a bit of a learning curve, but soon you'll find yourself getting into the swing of all the different Boons (power-ups) you can get from the pantheon. Every god/dess can add their own unique flair to your basic moves, whether that's more power, status effects, or something else. The variety is delightful, making each run unique, and you'll have fun testing out different combos. There are six different main weapons as well, each with four different Aspects (versions), for even more mixing and matching when you unlock them. It may seem like a lot at first, but you'll soon find yourself memorizing everything from sheer experience. There's a lot of different enemies to beat, but get used to their patterns and you'll succeed. Put enough time into the game and you might find that playing a run even becomes a way to de-stress, or at least it did for me.

[b]Music:[/b] Wonderful. Darren Korb is as incredible as always. You'll find the game's music stuck in your head, and it really lends a great atmosphere while you're playing. I sing along wholeheartedly to the songs with lyrics. You can unlock songs in the game, but I also highly recommend the soundtrack. And let's not forget the music played in-game by Zagreus himself, if he perseveres through enough practice. He's no prodigy, but it adds fun flavor.

[b]Art:[/b] Stunning. Jen Zee does not disappoint. The unique, colorful style of the game just pops, very eye-catching. Every part of the underworld has its own cool aesthetic, and you can add to it yourself as well by purchasing certain renovations. And of course, all of the characters have spectacular detailed designs that stand out from each other, showing that beauty isn't limited to appearing any specific way.

[b]Other:[/b] As if all the big main components of this game weren't amazing enough, it's all the little things that add up to this truly remarkable experience as well. I died after a long streak of successful runs, which of course was disappointing, and one of the characters commented on it and encouraged Zagreus. The fact that there's a Supportive Shade in Elysium is just so cute, and I definitely acknowledge them every time, just as I pet Cerberus after every run. Yes, you can pet the good boy, the real mark of an excellent game. I am so terribly glad [spoiler]that they didn't make us fight the dog, the possibility of which seriously scared me the first time I got up to Styx and saw him.[/spoiler]

This game is incredible. I never thought I would enjoy a rogue-like, but after seeing all the awards it won and how cheap it was on sale, I had to give it a shot.

The art, music, and quality of voice acting are off the charts. It's astounding that there's very little repeated dialog. You can tell this game was made by very passionate people. It's very refreshing to see so much love and care go into a game instead of the rushed crap many AAA game studios are pushing out.

As for combat, this has a very fresh and fun take. Each god generally has one or two ways to buff each of your three attacks, called "boons". Each god offers additional boons that further expand on the attack boons. For example, Poseidon makes your attacks knock enemies away. There's another Poseidon boon called "Razor Shoals" where if you knock an enemy away, that enemy takes damage if it moves. Additionally, there's "duo boons" that can only be unlocked if you have specific attack boons from specific gods. So if you pick 2-3 gods and focus on them, you get some very strong combinations and a very unique combat style for that run, which keeps this game fresh for a very long time.

I highly recommend this game, it's been a blast. When I came across the end credits, I thought, "oh neat. That was fun. Can I keep going? I still have a lot I want to get done." And it lets you keep going! At this time of writing, I'm almost to the epilogue. I'm hoping to 100% this game, which I've never had the patience to do with any other game before.

I'm not normally into rogue-like/lite games, but boy am I glad to have been able to try out this one. If having to replay same levels over and over again inescapably makes you feel like a hamster trapped in a wheel, this game will make you feel like a hamster who purchased a fancy exercise wheel that tastefully accompanies you on your rodent fitness journey with clever and entertaining motivational messages while dispensing healthy gourmet treats at appropriate intervals. [Holy cognitive re-framing, Batman!]

Strange metaphors aside, the game is indeed an audio and visual treat. Beautiful art concept with plenty of adorable little details to pay attention to, like the emote reactions of random shades (which btw I really wish they'd made available as Steam emoticons) or tiny candles being blown out by your attacks.
Many times, particularly at the start, I had to just stop and admire the decor or observe random background events that have no impact on the gameplay or story - Hades doing administrative work, Dusa and Meg gossiping on a girls' night out, random shades talking about the often ironic circumstances of their demise.
You've probably already heard that the music is amazing, and it really is great, from background battle sequences to vocal tracks. And the voice acting... wow! Every character is memorable, every dialogue is enjoyable. Including that one (quite important) character who basically speaks zombie. Also, mad props to whoever voiced Tisiphone... I actually got really curious to hear what she'll have to say every time I was about to meet her (more like 'how' rather that 'what', hard to explain without spoiling the encounter for new players), & I have to say, the er... character development was an amusing surprise.

The story is a tongue-in-cheek modernized take on a certain Greek myth, with a corporate twist. It's very well written, entertaining and at a certain point even emotional. I don't know if they made a gazillion recordings or if the lines are so well randomized, maybe it's both, but I barely noticed any repetition. Even after I finished the game, all achievements included, I still encounter lines that I haven't heard before here and there, and there's always something to make me chuckle.

Gameplay-wise, it's usually pretty easy to figure out the best tactics for each weapon. No rocket science. Except maybe when you get a certain ancient Greek weapon  The rewards system encourages you to switch it up and rotate your weaponry each escape attempt. Controls are simple, minimal finger nimbleness required. You'll receive random power-ups on your way, and while you will acquire limited tools to re-roll certain choices, you'll mostly be at the mercy of the Fates, i.e. RNG. In terms of play style, you can try going more in-depth by doing a bit of wiki diving and pre-planning your build, or you can just pick whatever seems good enough in the moment. I've been able to successfully escape with both approaches, so... you're free to do as you may. :)

Lots of love and talent was put into this game, and it was an absolute delight to come back to, over and over again, for a few achievement-grinding laps in Hell.

I have no patience for games that are difficult just for the sake of being difficult. As such, I was wary on buying this, but I'm glad I did. First of all trial and error isn't that harsh in this game. For example, you don't have to memorize what every god can give you since you can unlock codex that you can check any time. And there's a lot of freedom in your build, the RNG has a habit of maybe not giving you exactly what you need, but giving something you can still work with.

Secondly there's God mode, which you can turn on and off at will. It simply gives you 20% damage resistance upfront, with extra 2% each time you die. Which in practice isn't that much since most enemies will do like 1-20 damage, and yet it still feels comforting to see that 2% up when you die. Instead of punishing you after death (like taking away half of your health), it rewards you for your resilience. It takes away some of the bitterness of failure, giving you a small push to keep moving forward because you're literally getting stronger.

So yeah, as a casual gamer with memory problems, I thank you Supergiant Games. Hades has been an amazing experience.

I'm not normally into rogue-like/lite games, but boy am I glad to have been able to try out this one. If having to replay same levels over and over again inescapably makes you feel like a hamster trapped in a wheel, this game will make you feel like a hamster who purchased a fancy exercise wheel that tastefully accompanies you on your rodent fitness journey with clever and entertaining motivational messages while dispensing healthy gourmet treats at appropriate intervals. [Holy cognitive re-framing, Batman!]

Strange metaphors aside, the game is indeed an audio and visual treat. Beautiful art concept with plenty of adorable little details to pay attention to, like the emote reactions of random shades (which btw I really wish they'd made available as Steam emoticons) or tiny candles being blown out by your attacks.
Many times, particularly at the start, I had to just stop and admire the decor or observe random background events that have no impact on the gameplay or story - Hades doing administrative work, Dusa and Meg gossiping on a girls' night out, random shades talking about the often ironic circumstances of their demise.
You've probably already heard that the music is amazing, and it really is great, from background battle sequences to vocal tracks. And the voice acting... wow! Every character is memorable, every dialogue is enjoyable. Including that one (quite important) character who basically speaks zombie. Also, mad props to whoever voiced Tisiphone... I actually got really curious to hear what she'll have to say every time I was about to meet her (more like 'how' rather that 'what', hard to explain without spoiling the encounter for new players), & I have to say, the er... character development was an amusing surprise.

The story is a tongue-in-cheek modernized take on a certain Greek myth, with a corporate twist. It's very well written, entertaining and at a certain point even emotional. I don't know if they made a gazillion recordings or if the lines are so well randomized, maybe it's both, but I barely noticed any repetition. Even after I finished the game, all achievements included, I still encounter lines that I haven't heard before here and there, and there's always something to make me chuckle.

Gameplay-wise, it's usually pretty easy to figure out the best tactics for each weapon. No rocket science. Except maybe when you get a certain ancient Greek weapon [spoiler]a.k.a. the gun with an under-barrel grenade launcher. :)[/spoiler] The rewards system encourages you to switch it up and rotate your weaponry each escape attempt. Controls are simple, minimal finger nimbleness required. You'll receive random power-ups on your way, and while you will acquire limited tools to re-roll certain choices, you'll mostly be at the mercy of the Fates, i.e. RNG. In terms of play style, you can try going more in-depth by doing a bit of wiki diving and pre-planning your build, or you can just pick whatever seems good enough in the moment. I've been able to successfully escape with both approaches, so... you're free to do as you may. :)

Essentially the goal of the game is to escape from hell, using random gifts from Greek Gods to make you stronger as you progress. At first you'll probably be dying a lot, but you get to take back the treasure you picked up and use it to gradually make yourself stronger, unlocking more weapons, buffs and letting the story unfold. I think what this game does better than Isaac or Dead Cells is that no run feels totally wasted, you always have something to bring back even from a terrible escape attempt and there's always some sort of plot point expanded upon which helps keep things from going stale.
I'm still working through a lot of the story elements even now, the characters are all wonderful in their own ways and despite having vast amounts of dialogue everything's fully voice acted. I am just floored by how far I've come and still getting to hear new dialogue every single time, this game just went all out with the presentation.
If I could pick one thing I think was comparatively disappointing, I'd say it's the lack of locations. It's always the exact same number of rooms per zone with only four locales in total in the same order every time. It would have been nice if there were branching paths for different zones like other games of this type. Also a small nitpick but sometimes each room can be rather large and occasionally there are urns that hold currency, it's a pain to scour each room checking to make sure you didn't miss it and I wish they'd put them next to the exits instead.
But yeah, fantastic game, totally deserves all the awards it got and I'll be playing more for some time yet.

For me personally, Hades is an overall example of how to captivate a player and don't let go. It wasn't long after I started playing that I realized that I had been looking for a game like this. The main reasons for this are:

1) [u][b]Keyboard and Mouse[/b][/u] friendly! I've play only with KB&M and except for rebinding the special attack to my mouse button, there was no limitation or disadvantage I could think of‚Ä¶
1) [u][b]"Boon" system[/b][/u] and different weapons, which keeps the game reasonably fresh for most of the playthrough even if you want to complete everything
2) I would say its [u][b]difficulty[/b][/u] is great as it's not hard to get through all the bosses within first hours/days (depending on your gaming experience and commitment), but then additional challenges become available which can make your life difficult very quickly
3) [u][b]World design & artwork[/b][/u] is amazing and it's easy to fall in love with everything even if you don't know much about the Greek mythology*
4) [u][b]Soundtrack[/b][/u] which you encounter throughout the game is all it needs to be and a bit extra. There are moments in the game where most players just stop for a moment to appreciate everything the game has to offer

Something I also truly appreciate in a game like this are the dialogues. I have no idea how long it took to write and then dub everything, but if someone told me it took years, I would believe it. Not only there are friendly, serious and hostile interactions of the main character with everyone, but there are interactions between all the other character as well, which is another reason why it's nearly impossible to get bored in this game. And some interactions are pretty funny :)

*
[u][b]One recommendation for people, who don't know much about the mythology:[/b][/u]
If you can, play this game with someone, who can explain all the easter eggs and references, because playing with my partner who is obsessed with the Greek mythology since their childhood is what made my love for this game into an obsession. Pretty much everything makes sense and is surprisingly accurate (except for a few understandable details), so understanding the relations and symbolism in this game can actually translate into some fun knowledge of the real mythology. And all that while playing an awesome game! Also, it makes the interactions funnier :)

Every aspect of this game is done with perfection. 
The story revolves around Zagreus, a prince of the underworld and the son of Hades, trying to escape the domains of the underworld to reach the surface and rekindle the relationship of his long lost mother Persephone. The characters in this game are just fantastic with each of them being given a multitude of dialog and personality and being backed with some amazing voice acting. The story and the way that it is written is so well done as it manages to balance both progression and story telling perfectly as the player will be learning new information about the plot each time they attempt a run and return to the main hub area. 
The setting of the underworld is impressively diverse as each area hold its own kind of tonality and I would go as far as to say that it can be seen as it's own character as it also manages to tell the story through each floor you encounter. 
Visually, its absolutely gorgeous. Supergiant games have always had a unique art direction and i believe that this game brings out the best in that. The way each character, level, item, etc looks in this game is just incredible and it clearly stands out from both other indie games and previous Supergiant games titles. 
Highlighting that this is a Supergiant games production, the soundtrack and audio are once again such a pleasure to enjoy. The soundtrack is just filled with moments that best fit the game, from intense and exciting battles to calm friendly encounters. The audio is just perfect with pretty much anything aural related being top par. 
In terms of gameplay, this is a brilliant rogue-like experience. The combat that you have in game feels very smooth and  fitting for any style that you may choose. There are 6 weapons to choose from, all with their own move sets and i believe that the game balances them pretty fairly. The enemies are also pretty varied with each of them offering the player a new challenge to try and overcome. The boss fights are incredible as nearly all of them will have some change to them each time you do a new run. The boon system is really well done with the player being able to pick and choose what buffs they want to carry on into the run. Items that you obtain in the runs can be used for all sorts of things such as upgrading your Zagreus, unlocking both weapons and abilities, creating bonds with other characters in the game, renovating both the hub world and the arenas. This game offers a lot to players but never lack in any aspects that it provides. 
Overall, Hades is a near (if not) perfect game that manages to push all boundaries and succeeds in all of them and i would recommend this game to anyone wanting a unique and impressive experience.

first, let's talk about the gameplay. in the game you play as zagreus, prince of the underworld, using various blessings from the gods, various trinkets, and the 6 infernal arms to break free from various regions of your father's domains to reach the surface. each of the infernal arms plays very different to any of the others and each of them has 4 aspects if you bother to seek them all out, so the base gameplay has the potential to be very diverse. you can also modify these weapons and how you play them based on the boons and enchantments you get throughout the run, ensuring that no two runs are really alike in terms of gameplay. the combat is very well done and satisfying and easy to get into.

i've seen some comments saying that hades is a very polished overall game, but not a good contender in the roguelite genre, which i have to agree on. while, yes, no two runs are alike, the amount of variety in basically any other aspect of this game is quite limited. first of all, in adherence to mythology, there are only so many underworld regions you can play through in the game, and there are only so many boss versions you can fight against. variety in these comes from the rooms you choose and the boss versions you randomly encounter, which is certainly enough for most casual players here for the story, but if you want to play for the roguelite element, then you'd do best to expect diminishing returns from replaying. another gripe i have with the roguelite element is how the game handles difficulty. hades equates difficulty to taking away your advantages rather than giving you disadvantages and advantages you have to work your way around, which i don't think is good roguelite design. this makes the game harder, but it does not make you want to keep getting better and playing the harder modes, because it ceases to be fun at some point. contrast this with other roguelites like dead cells and you immediately see the difference; 20+ heat in hades is intense and engaging, while 5BC in dead cells is the same but also fun and fair. but for most players this is not an issue at all since it'll take most players a long, long time to get to heat of that level unless you choose to play just one weapon every run, which isn't very fun. 

the story centers around the theme of family and zagreus' journey to reunite his own, which is done through his runs through the underworld, meeting various gods of olympus and hades and deepening bonds with them to eventually be able to bring them all together. it's a tale that i personally wasn't too invested in since i wanted to play for the gameplay, but let's just say that it blends very well with the roguelite genre and it makes the player want to play again and again to see it through to completion. to this i say compliments to the devs for making a story based roguelite, which is a true rarity.

as most people know, the art in this game is absolutely phenomenal, and the consistent quality of voice lines and attention to detail continues to amaze me even after putting over 70 hours into the game. the various side quests you can do by helping out members of the court of hades is also very rewarding for players as anyone well-versed in greek mythology will understand the lore and significance of zagreus's actions. i guess what i'm trying to say here is that having some level of understanding of greek mythology is the cherry on top for this game. 

that's about it. you should definitely play this game even if you're not a pogchamp pro gamer (trademark) because like i mentioned earlier, this game is just an overall very well polished game that just happens to be a roguelite
